transcript.content: [~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Can we just remind...
Go on.
... can I just check that again...
Go on.
... so he's made a fool out of the MD...
He's made a fool out of the MD...
... and all the major... basically all the Capital shareholders...
... all this... all this shit about "oh, I'm not sure if I'm coming back or not, I... okay, I want a day off then", which is the same day off as his girlfriend gets off...
Convenient.
... so he's just like, walking 'round, I dunno, Hyde Park...
Yeah.
... feeding ducks, when he should be working out what he can do instead of Rockbusters, which is basically Blockbusters with a word changed.
Steve laughs
Christ's sake. Right, little tw...
If that's... if that's annoyed you...
What?
... I'll tell you what has really wound me up...
Go on.
... the last week or so - this postal strike.
Ricky sniggers
I tell you, Rick, I have got no sympathy for them. I'd be a scab, I'd be walking through there, and I'd be...
Ricky laughs
No, and I'd be giving them the finger, I'd go, "you can intimidate my family, I don't care. I don't care, because the post has gotta get through".
Yeah.

'Cause I'll tell you what - um, it's not the fact... you know, the unions, they can organise a strike, I'm behind that, that's fair enough. But not when it's these wildcats. They're just out there, they're just taking days off, willy-nilly! They're not... they're...
Well...
... they're sealing up the postboxes, it's going crazy!
Maybe Karl could deliver a few bags on Monday, so if you...
Well, I know... I know Karl must be livid cause it's probably his copies of the New Scientist...
Ricky laughs
... and the Literary Review haven't turned up. So he's... he's in a terrible way. And uh, I got important documents that are supposed to be coming to me...
Yeah.
There's nothing.
Yeah.
There's hide nor hair of it. And I was cooking last night and I... it got me panicked, 'cause I was thinking about... if this just is gonna spread now, amongst other organisations and other groups...
Yeah.
... and do you know what, it was partly...
Like a cancer.
... it was partly 'cause I was cooking...
Yeah.
... but do you know who I suddenly become terrified that they might go on strike?
Go on.
The guys in charge of the potatoes.
Oh... I'll tell you what...
I mean, anyone involved with potatoes. The farmers...
... I had so much mash last night...
... I had so much sausage and mash, right, I had second helpings, that I had to sit on the edge of a seat so my stomach could hang down.
It's...
I love spuds. Spuds and bread, I could not do without spuds and bread.
But I feel... I feel like maybe I could make my own bread. Spuds - I wouldn't know where to start with a spud.
Yeah.
And it's... they're amazing, you can boil them, you can broil them.
Yeah.
I don't know what broiling is...
Nor do I.
... but it's... I suspect it's tasty.
I don't... I don't think it's as good as... I mean, obviously the chipped potato is everyone's favourite.
For the working classes, the chip.
Oh, it was always on. The chip fat fryer was always on in my household. The ceiling... the uh... you know, the deathtrap fire, um, whatsit, polystyrene ceiling was yellow...
Steve laughs
Yeah. Exactly. Yeah.
... come Wednesday in our house.
Yeah.
And uh, it... yeah, always had chips, or...
Because... all I remember hearing, if I think back to my childhood, all I remember was, um... "gotta stop and get some potatoes", or "phone your dad, tell him to get some potatoes".
Well that was... that was your job, wasn't it? Karl?
To get the potatoes?
Yeah, yeah, yeah. It was like...
I mean, it genuinely, it does concern me, because it's...
What did you have to do? Didn't you have to... didn't you have to fill a diary out for your teacher?
Well it was when... do you know when you're at school... I don't know if you did the same thing, but you get like a little red book, right, and every night... I think it was a way of...
... the teacher sort of keeping an eye on you, so if you went out robbing, if you wrote it in your diary, they'd go "what are you playing at?"
Sure.
Right? So you'd have to write down what you did every night.
Yeah.
Ricky sniggers
But I didn't get up to that much, at that point...
Sure.
... I used to just go on my errands...
Yeah.
... and it was my job to like...
I haven't heard 'errand' for... since the seventies.
No, it's nice to hear that.
... just, just...
Go on.
... I went to Hugh Fay's, right, the little local supermarket.
Ricky sniggers
... and I got, um...
What's it called? Euthan... euthanasia?
Ricky chuckles
What? I didn't...
You...
You...
Hugh Fay's.
You... New Phase? New Phase?
You? You Phase? You?
Hugh Fay's. Right?
Yeah?
H-U-G-H. Hugh Fay's.
Oh, Hugh Fay is his name.
Oh, it's his name.
Right.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And uh, I just...
"Right, New Phase, alright, yeah."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

She's studying product designed for the fashion industry. And Anyway, she's got some questionnaire and we're obviously we're too busy and important to fill out the questionnaire, but we thought maybe you can answer it Karl.

Look at Karl look he's yawning. He's looking around. He's only got to do two hours and he gets a whole day off and he's getting paid for it do something Karl be grateful. You've probably you've probably ruined a man's career. He's ridiculed now for doing this that he's so weak where he should have slapped, squoze your head and kicked you out of the building. So let's have a little bit of effort. You've only got an hour and a quarter to do then you get two days off. All right
All right
Right Karl, It's a questionnaire about happiness.
Oh, yeah,
There's one person... Well that should answer it right there. First question Karl on a happy scale of 1 to 10. Where are you on the happy scale
Is it this moment or in general?
Well, I would say generally
Okay.
Yeah, but you don't always have to like, I mean
Oh Jesus Christ...
I think I'm happy and that but I don't always show it
You never show it.

No, but it doesn't mean I'm not I'm not happy and that like I'm alright at the moment I'd say I'm probably on a, I was probably on about an eight. I was probably on about a nine when I woke up. All right, and then sort of fell out with Suzanne her haircut. She went for a haircut and came back with something that I didn't like
Sorry what did you say you...  so, so when your girlfriend walked through the door after she had her hair done And you said I don't like it, alright?.
Well she can tell by the look on my face and I said
But don't say no I'm happy with it you just can't tell, I'm loving it
Because then she might have it done again
Oh Karl I just cannot get over you. I really can't I cannot
No but you haven't seen it so so then I was fed up
Sorry what authority have you got to talk about haircuts.

Yeah, you had that you had the, well officially from a barber in Manchester above a railway station in a shack. It was two pounds a cut told you have the hair of a Chinaman. Well you wish you had the hair of a Chinaman now you got no hair,  you're a little bald manc with your mouth open so don't... Is she listening to this Suzanne? sitting at home with a woolly hat on
I dunno. but she knows now doesn't she?
What did you say? What words did you say?
What could she do about it though?
I just said you look like someone out of Slade
*laughs*
Interestingly, that's what I look for in a girlfriend.
Oh God
Which one of Slade?
That one with the funny hair.
Not Dave Hill.
Yeah
The one with the Crooked Fringe and the goofy teeth, she had her teeth done as well did she, she had two front teeth put in
Dump her.
So anyway
So, so prior to that you're on a nine, then you saw the haircut you're on an eight.
Yeah.
Now what you on?
I'm probably on about a six at the moment.
Why what's happened?
Well, whilst star sailor was on a bit more head squeezing going on.
*laughs*
So yeah about a five or six.
So generally speaking what would you say you're on?
About a four
You're on a four normally
*laughs*
All right, what would you give someone who wasn't very happy? What would you give them?
Err..
What are you thinking Karl, depends why they're not happy?
They're not, they're low, ok. So what would you give them?
I mean if you, yeah, depends dunnit, I mean if it's someone who's just lost their arms and legs in an accident you don't give him a lollipop
Sure, or some mittens.
*laughs* You give them a hat.
Yeah and dare I say it a smile
A skateboard.
Yeah, yeah.
I dunno.
Well no, you've got to answer the question
All right so hang on let's assume that you've upset your girlfriend Cause you've slagged off her haircut?
What are you gonna do now to make her happy?
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Beautiful.

Billy Bragg from his essential Billy Bragg compilation there. Now, I know a lot of people are thinking, "Billy Bragg, oh, can't be bothered. Politics." And I have to say, buy this CD. Skip past every song that is, for instance, "There is power in a union."
"Don't be duped by fascism".
Yeah. "It's your right and duty to vote."
Yeah. "Right wing, wrong wing."
Exactly. Ignore all that, just listen to the love songs.
His love songs are beautiful.
Yeah.
It's fantastic, new - "Tonight I celebrate my love for you with a pint of beer and a new tattoo." He's great.
Brilliant.
Lose the ones about, yeah --
Exactly.
-- striking.
Yeah exactly. Because we know what we think of that so yeah, I highly recommend that and --
Karl. We're on happiness, Karl. I tried to explain to Karl that the aim to - you know, it's really to get on a 10.
Yeah. But I like the fact that he started on a 9!
But I love the fact he's happy with 4.
Yeah.
I love that.
No, but what - what I mean is, right, I'm not looking for, like, happiness.
Right.
I'm alright --
You're not looking for a penis, what? What's that for?
What I mean is, right, I'm happy when I'm not fed up. So what I mean is, I'm happy --

This is the - is this your new book, "Psychology of the Mind". What is that? "I'm happy when I'm not fed up." That's like an eight-year-old trying to explain happiness. Johnny, what is it when a- Im happy when Im not fed up. Well done. Good boy. That's it. You're happy when you're not fed up. Talk like an adult.
Yeah, but that's what I'm saying to you though. I dont
What?
I'm happy most of the time, it's just that when things niggle me, I find that - I realize when I'm annoyed more than when I'm happy.
But Karl you - every time we talk to you, youre whinging about something. You got something that annoys you.

But hes one of those people that if he whinges loud enough, he gets away with it. Like, hes in here - I think  he goes, Oh Im really busy, right? I come in and he's doing nothing. He's chatting because he's having big long chats with everyone about how someone's wound him up and they all come in and go, Oh, Karls all fed up. Because hes got this show. You know what I mean? Hes wormed his way
No, but hang on a minute.
Go on.
You came in - you came in moaning about the post and that today.
Yeah.
But everyone's annoyed and frustrated by that, theres small businesses going out of business.
Im not, Im not. You havent heard me
No youre not, because whos sending you letters? No one. You've got no friends.
Mmm. Well
You said that yourself.
Yeah.
You've openly declared you don't want friends, theyre too much hassle.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah. That is - that is my joy - friends is that - that is the point of life to me. It's - I can't wait to see them. I squeeze their head. I welcome them in.
Mmm.
They annoy me.
Friends annoy me. I love it. Friends are annoying. Hes even scared of, like, doing summat with a friend or getting a gift because he goes, Oh I have to buy them one back now.
Yeah.
It's sort of like life's a bit of a chore for Karl, innit?
Well anyway, alright, let's leave that aside. Obviously, youre never going to be entirely happy. Although apparently you are already on the brink of happiness.
No, what Im saying is --
All you have to say is, Your hair looks nice. That's all you had to say. Yeah, it was good, yeah. And that's it, end of story.
What's the point in that? What is the point in that?
Because she doesn't really - she doesn't really care what you think, but she doesn't want to hear that she looks like Dave Hill from Slade.
Shes not having a haircut just to please you Karl, despite what you might think.
Yeah.
He's taken aback by that.
Yeah. Yeah. Yeah.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Uh, this is Racist FM, 104.9.
Yeah. So who would you like to see bombed? Or - not bombed. Not bombed, but just put the frighteners on them.
Yeah, who would you scare
Email ricky.gervais@xfm.co.uk.
of anyone, any nation or anything. Karl, thoughts?
Play a song?

Yeah, you're not working for your money, youre not having Monday off. We've got to do summat Monday. Let's plan summat Monday just to get him in here. You've got - two hours for eight hours off. You don't do an eight hour day anyway, but
Rick, how much is he getting paid?

Hes get - hes getting money for this. His wage - I think his wage went up last time. So hes getting paid to be here. Extracurricular, extra work. Right? And so it's moonlighting. And theyve given him a day off.
Yeah.
And hes contributing nothing.
Nothing.
*mumbles*
Huh? What, Karl? Did you say summat, mate?
*mumbles*
Huh?
Its going on.
What?
Going on with yourself.
Well, say summat back and earn your money!
Well, lets - lets just play a song. We've done a bit - done a bit of stuff there.
You idiot.
Dont say we there, Ive not heard anything from you. Weve heard your contributions.

P.I.M.P, 50 Cent on XFM 104.9. Me, Ricky Gervais. Uh, you, Stephen Merchant. And you, Karl Pilkington. All right? What we doing then? How are we going? Karl, how are you feeling? How - what - I need you on a scale of 10 now, happiness scale.
I, uh - just building back up again a bit.
Yeah? What?
Probably on about a 5.
Oh, thats not bad.
Why, what - what - what changed it? What changed it?
Just - just calmed down a bit.
Yeah.
So
The chilled out vibes of P.I.M.P probably helped you.
Yeah.
I think we should just say, um - give massive props to Adam and Joe who stood in for us.
Oh yeah, stood in for us. Uh, I
Just for a couple of months. Did a great job.
Yeah, great, really good. That
In fact, interestingly though, listening to their show
Are they gonna give them their own - are they gonna get their own show here? I think they should.
Yeah, theyll probably get something.
Well, there you go.

Well, um, it's interesting, as I was listening to them, they had quite a nice selection of features. They had a couple of good competitions and things. Now, I don't know if, um, having done them for XFM, is it somehow - they may be kind of under some kind of XFM copyright? Which would mean as we've got no ideas, maybe we could just hijack some of theirs?
Just nick some of theirs.
Maybe you could look into that. Obviously not Monday, youre not here, but
I was with Joe Cornish last night. I went to a little, um, do at, um, uh, Jonathan's house and Joe was there. And he walked in and I was taken aback by how tall he is.
Sure.
Because I've - Id forgotten. And he's about 64. But hes an unlikely - do you know what I mean by that?
Mmm, mmm.

It's sort of like some people surprise you. And he was going, You know, it's - I don't consider, um, 64 big. I said, It is pretty big. I said, But I know what you mean, I walk around with Steve Merchant.
Yeah.
And uh, he went, How tall is Steve? 66, 6 foot 7.
Yep.
And Joe went, Oh that's - that's - that's nearly a disability, isn't it?

Do you know, he's absolutely right as far as Im concerned. No, do you know, I genuinely - since school, I used to go to school with a little disabled fella. Lovely guy. No, I swear to God, lovely guy. And do you know, I remember him he came in when when we got in the sixth form and he basically got - I don't know what the ins and outs of it were, but as far as I could tell, he's got a car for free. A specially converted car.
Yeah.
You know, because he's disabled
...and... (ricky starts talking over steve)
Same as Karl - "me, me me ". I need this. I need that.

But it seemed to me that, I was thinking why can I not get something similar because there are some cars I can fit in, because I'm too tall. I genuinely cannot drive the smaller cars - the cheaper cars. I've got obliged to buy a more expensive larger car because I can't fit in the tiny ones.
That's like saying you've got to pay more for your shoes cause there's more leather which is true.
Which is absolutely true, it's a nightmare getting shoes.
Yeah yeah yeah, but fat people have to pay more...
Do you know what? It's a nightmare getting chairs - comfy chairs that I can sit in at home. If I sit in a chair for very long my back's killing me. Now. How is that not a disability?
But no, I don't see, you don't see people like me whinging!

But I think tall people err, I read an article that taller people and average err, get, err, higher wages through something through, you know an advantage OR just because they're taken more seriously than little dumpy fellas
Sure...
Do you know what I mean?
I don't think there are...
So it's swings and roundabouts.
...I Genuinely don't think there are many benefits of being really tall, people seem to assume there are, but beyond the fact that I can reach things down from a high shelf.
I know.
I don't think there's any real perks.
I've seen you hit your head a few times.
I know I've seen it a few times and I think "oh God that must have hurt". Obviously. I'll make sure okay and then laugh.
Course!
But I know that must be annoying.
Thanks mate...
No, but I mean... there's a pub. There's one pub in SoHo that he has to go down backwards, he has to lean back! looks like a limbo dancer.
Yeah, they've almost got to lower me in on ropes.
I always find it amusing! Oh dear...
(inaudible) on an airplane, I can't get, some of the seats, I can't fit in some of the seats, not in anyway... not that (ricky starts talking over steve)
Because some people...
WHAT ARE YOU TALKING ABOUT, HOW IS THAT NOT A DISABILITY!?
There's some seats that people can't afford because they're poor it's not a disability.
THAT'S IRRELEVANT! Don't go on a plane then because you're poor!
But!
If you can't afford to go on a plane, you can't aford to go on a plane. You should have studied hard at school.
But what annoy, yeah but I mean what annoys me about that is, there's... there's... there's...
This is a physical disability born with!
There's a there's a weight allowance. So I might not be allowed loads of bags on but there might be a big fat pig in the queue is about the same chocolate allowance as me.

But that's because they've been eating like a bloater. I couldn't stop myself from growing this tall. It wasn't a conscious decision. I didn't think "I'll tell you why I won't I won't smoke when I'm a teenager".
Maybe I'll shoot up,
(ricky laughs)
I'll eat healthy. I'll probably add an extra two feet. It just kept going!
You do eat too Healthy, you eat way too many greens.
But that's not why I grew to this height, isn't it?
Yeah, but if you'd lived near, I don't know, some sort of pylon or something and just, as I say, smoked from an early age, you wouldn't have been that tall.
Don't think when I was at gangly teenager having the piss taken at me, I wasn't thinking "I wish I'd been born near a pylon".
Could you...
You know or Chernobyl...
Could your mam or dad like, could've, could they have bandaged you like they did with little...
Didn't they do that with someone's feet?
Well, yeah (ricky and steve talk over eachother)
I didn't come out this tall, did I?
No but (ricky, steve AND karl talk over eachother)
HOW would they bandage him? They'd have to bandage him around the feet around the top of the head.
Yeah. I'd be walking around looking like a mummy.
Yeah. Yeah. Yeah a bonsai Boy!
But people didn't really realize I was going to be this tall until I was 14 or 15, you know, you don't realize when you're an eight-year-old as everyone's taller, aren't thet?
How tall were you about like a gangly - okay - so typical gangly teenager? 15! How tall were you a 15!
Dunno... 6'5" maybe?
Ricky laughs
And I bet you're like a beanpole weren't ya?
Of course.
Yeah, what sort of glasses did you have?
Cool.
No, what did you have?
I don't know - a monocle.
Ricky laughs
No, I can't remember.
Didn't you wear a bowtie once?

I thought... I thought... I was trying to preempt the styles that might be cominground. I think I'd been watching a lot of George Formby films and I thought it could only be a lot... it can only be a matter of time before the Bowtie comes in. I thought you might be quite kind of Urbane and debonair.
Yeah.
So all (inadible).
Was Robin day at the height of his fame?
I think he might.
Around this time... Yeah.
I want to go for that Dandy look, I thought that's what the girls are looking for.
Dandy! I know yeah...
The Dandy...
Ohhh, dear...
Just to see you with a pipe and Trilby.
Yeah
I just think you'd look great walking along the street.
What about a boater?
Boater... yeah.
But genuinely, it really does frustrate me that I don't get any allowance as (inaudible).
It doesn't count as a disability...
It does count!
No it doesn't, it's not a disability being six foot seven.
But how can you explain for instance, you know traveling on a bus or coach - there's some seats I can't sit in.
The only disadvantage is people look at you. I HAVE seen people stare at you, umm but they stare at me because I've been on the telly!
What's that a disability? people being recognized...
Yes, but you could avoid that by not being on the Telly. It's your choice. This is my point. It's your choice.
Yeah ok...
It's the same as a big fat people. It's their choice.
It's a different sort of stare, isn't it? I've been there.
Yeah.
When you know the sort of stare that you get and sort of these sort stare steve gets.
Well, obviously, I'm sorry Steve. I'm going to, you know, follow this enquiry - what do you mean karl?
So I'm just saying it's more of a stare of fear than like, with you the go "Oh it's him!".
Yeah go on...
Whereas with you. It's more like... Geeze...
Ricky shrieks
Do you know what frustrates me?
What?
I thought he did deserve having a Monday off - I've changed my tune.
Yeah
Sometimes I mean you don't realize this listeners, but sometimes I'm an intermediary. I do step in when he's winding him up, because Karl gets to the point where he's going to explode.
Yeah (talking over steve) It's okay gerv...
It's crazy. And I step in, and this is the kind of response I get from Karl. The kind of backchat I get.
Well I told you! He's a little user!
I'll tell you what because he's too scared of winding you up because he knows that you're just walk out of here and he won't get his Monday off.
Absolutely play a record. You little oik.
Weasel... you're a weasel.
Song starts.
Jo Jackson - Different for Girls

Jo Jackson - Different for Girls and Xfm 104.9... Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant Karl Pilkington. He's annoying me now because he's got a day off and he's got two hours and he's miserable, he's not even doing anything for the show, it really annoys me.
Well, hang on. Wait a minute. You've forgotten His brilliant film quiz.
Yeah.
He's contributed that.
That he probably did during the week.
Do you know what I mean?
Well...
Are you change your attitude Karl, or what? or shall we just like... not bother with this show?
Told you - don't annoy me and you'll get the best out of me.Yeah?
Okay. I told you, I told you, this show is to annoy you you knew that!
But this is what you're gonna get. Do you know what I mean?
But no, you've got, a you've got to be good and get the day off or there's no point... for any of us.
Right, if you have an operation, would you annoy the doctor?
What...? (laughing)
He can't concentrate can he? Don't wind him up...
I love the fact he's a doctor.
All of sudden?
Yeah. He's got a press of button.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

synopsis.description: Steve is too tall for chairs.
Karl suspects they could have bandaged steve to stop him getting so tall.
With you, it's more like... Geeze...
